Might want to call it out specifically or clarify the wording to show that this is the desired state. "For option values or combinations of option name and value, use I()"
I've added some comments jtyr's PR https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/20931 and we can have that discussion there.

comments.body:
I wonder if we want a pull box somewhere that reiterates the string rather than float message with some rationale?

Maybe soemthing like:
```
.. note:: Versions should be strings

    In general, care should be taken to list versions as strings rather than floats.  This has
    several reasons:
    * Versions may not always be floats, for instance "2.1.0" or "2.0alpha1".
    * Versions may not compare correctly if used as a float.  A float will tempt
       naive comparison between 2.3 and 2.12 which won't generate the correct
       ordering.  Strings "2.3" and "2.12" require a bit of code which will let the
       programmer do it correctly.
On the other hand, maybe that belongs in the programming modules section of the developer docs.  Perhaps a link from here to that (eventual) section would be the right way to go.

I'll add that `.. note::` in here for the moment. It's useful to people to understand *why* we require certain things. 

Can  always move this in the future if we end up writing anything about how to compare versions.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +47,51 @@* ``version_added:``
  The version of Ansible when the module was added.
  This is a `string`, and not a float, i.e. ``version_added: "2.1"``
* ``author:``
  Name of the module author in the form ``First Last (@GitHubID)``. Use a multi-line list if there is more than one author.

comments.body: Because the module documentation is generated from documentation strings contained in the modules, all modules included with Ansible must have a ``DOCUMENTATION`` string.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +4,8 @@```````````````````````

The online module documentation is generated from the modules themselves.
As the module documentation is generated from documentation strings contained in the modules, all modules included with Ansible must have a ``DOCUMENTATION`` string.
This string must be a valid YAML document

comments.body:
I'd make these links to the relevant sections below.

For linking in general we need to think about how we want to use ref: http://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/stable/markup/inline.html#ref-role  Currently our ref targets are all thrown into the same namespace.  The documentation has gotten big enough that we should think of splitting that a bit.  Probably having a set of high level categories and  prefixing the category name to the ref makes sense.  (That way we can have multiple references to an idea like:  cfg_pipelining, plugin_connection_pipelining, intro_pipelining)  Maybe dev_guide is a sufficient prefix or perhaps dev_mods?
Agreed, though I'm going to make this a problem for the future (and I'd want to get Scott's input)
I've added a TOC in now, so that should make it easier for people to navigate the page

comments.body: so this is 3rd version i've seen, original was 'curated', modules currently use 'committer' and now we are adding 'core_curated'?

Not that it is necessarily the source of truth, but validate-modules sets the schema to this field as:

```
        Required('supported_by'): Any('core', 'community', 'unmaintained',
                                      'committer')
```

This was done based off of the proposal, but I also see that the metadata tool lists:

core, curated, committer, community
weeee!
curated == commiter
new value different from example above

`The name of the module, This must be the same as it would be used from a play.`

We have the problem of conflating audiences... I think the audience for this doc is modules that will be accepted into ansible/ansible (which others can look at for best practices but can vary as fits their needs.)
